Overall, the activities under this cluster will contribute to enhanced cross-border trade environment in the Philippines and, in the longer-term, they will be instrumental for strengthening the country’s position in international rankings and positive perception of its procedural and regulatory framework. This facilitated environment in turn will be essential for supporting economic growth and attracting investments to the country.

Through pre-departure meetings, an extensive dialogue process was undertaken with youth and women’s rights groups, including with the Asia-Pacific gender equality advocates, to discuss strategies for effective civil society participation at CSW67. This also led to framing a set of inputs to the draft CSW67 Agreed Conclusions. The recommendations emerging from the pre-departure meetings were presented to MWCD, Government of India, at the Asia-Pacific Pre-CSW meeting held on 8- 9 February 2023 in Bangkok. At CSW67, civil society delegates of UN Women participated in key events, including CSW Youth Forum that saw engagement and leadership of six Indian Youth Advocates in a parallel event, namely #FeministFutures: Young Feminists Co-leading Policy Advocacy on Technology and Innovation (led by NGYAs from India); and 2 side events, namely Leveraging Public-Private Commitment for Women’s Greater Access to Technology and Education (organized by UN Women India, G20 EMPOWER and Permanent Mission of India); and Grassroots Leadership and Transformation: Charting the Path of Empowerment Through Technology and Skill Development (organized by UN Women India, Women 20 and the Permanent Mission of India). In June 2023, UN Women organised two interaction meetings with Ms. Lopa Banerjee, UN Women’s Civil Society Division Head. One of the two interactions were organised with the CSO partners and the other with the CSAG members only. The meeting focused on a discussion related to be debriefing on 67th session of the commission of status of women. the scope and challenges with respect to participation in intergovernmental processes and the GEF platforms were discussed. the group shared reflections on strategies for supporting un women’s partnership with civil society in India and globally. In addition, a discussion was organised on feminist foreign policy with the CSO partner on 6th June 2023. A robust and vibrant feminist movement holds key stakeholders accountable, pushes for more progressive policies, legislation, and access to services, and supports the realization of the human rights of women and girls. Hence, as part of GEF, a national platform for Feminist Movement Mapping has been set up. UN Women supported the formation of feminist labs that brought together 30 youth leaders from India to develop a community of practice for young feminist movement building and leadership. The knowledge products developed a repository of practical guides and tools on how to participate and contribute to feminist youth-led interventions. In its first phase, this programme has achieved the strengthening of an ecosystem of 100 youth leaders, built cross-linkages and advanced discourse towards feminist youth leadership building. In June 2023, UN Women and its Responsible Party, Gender at Work India, launched the following five knowledge resources on young feminist leadership building. The resources are based on an understanding of the youth leadership landscape, opportunities and challenges in India with a focus on marginalized identities and assertions. •	A literature review of feminist youth leadership programme •	A white paper entitled, Reimagining Youth Programmes: Seeking Support for Intersectional Feminist Youth Leadership for Collective Action •	A Needs Assessment Report for the Feminist Youth Leadership Programme •	A Practitioner’s Workbook on Principles and Processes of Feminist Youth Leadership Building•	A Resource Toolkit for Youth Leaders and Gender Advocates•	Film on Young Feminist Leadership ProgrammeWHO India Country office- 1. 2024 Narrative: UN Women: In the reporting year, UN Women, in partnership with Gender at Work India Trust and Point of Views, adopted innovative modalities for institutional engagement with women’s rights organizations and civil society organizations (CSOs), leveraging intersectional, inter-generational, and multi-stakeholder approaches to advance gender equality. Modalities and Platforms Beijing+30 Review Process Six virtual consultations were organized by UN Women, alongside Gender at Work India Trust and Point of Views, as part of the Beijing+30 Review Process. This initiative marked the 30th anniversary of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action, aimed at advancing global gender equality. A Steering Committee of 14 experts was constituted in August 2024 to provide strategic guidance on achieving the goals set forth in the Beijing Declaration. Thematic Consultations Six thematic consultations were organized, focusing on Gender-Based Violence, Gender and Disability Rights, Power and Marginalization, Conflict, Peace and Security, Labour and Economy, and Gender and Climate Change. These consultations engaged over 454 participants, including diverse CSOs and grassroots organizations, to deliberate on critical challenges, strategies, and policy gaps aligned with the Beijing Declaration’s critical pillars. The outcomes of these discussions contributed to regional and global dialogues, with a focus on inclusive, intersectional advocacy. CEDAW Shadow Report Process UN Women initiated a confidential report on behalf of the UNCT, scheduled for submission in March 2025. This report will explore trends of pushback against CSOs and gender equality work in India. Additionally, the CEDAW reporting process integrates learning opportunities for grassroots organizations, ensuring that their voices are represented in policy-making processes.  ICO supported a youth leader who led a CSO delegation to the Asia-Pacific Ministerial Conference on the Beijing+30 Review, amplifying the voice of queer youth to resist systemic oppression, reclaim erased histories, and transform the socio-cultural norms that marginalize LGBTQIAP+ communities. The overall Objective of the project was to “Facilitate an enabling environment for migrants to gain collective bargaining power for an improved protective atmosphere at the workplace and gain access to state and national entitlements, through advisory support to Shahi Exports Pvt Ltd for institutionalising an MSC.” The partnership has helped catering to the needs of the migrant workers and facilitated support for accommodation, counselling services, identity documentation services, linking with healthcare services, networking with employers, grievance redressal, and other key services relevant for migrants.
